**** Etymology[edit] ****
Uncertain, but usually held to derive from Old_Chinese чзж (*zin) (sm Q├нn, mc
d═бzi╔кn, oc *zin, "Qin"), the westernmost ancient_Chinese_state.[1][2][3] Other
theories have been proposed, including derivation from цЩЙя╝ПцЩЛ (j├мn) (sm J├мn, mc
t═бsi╔кn, oc *╩Фsins, "Jin"), another important ancient state;[4] шНКя╝ПшНЖ (j─лng) (sm
J─лng, mc k╦аi├ж┼Л, oc *ke┼Л, "Chu"), the southernmost ancient Chinese state;[5] or
Zina, the endonym of the people of the Yelang kingdom.[5] See "Names_of_China"
and "Chinas" at Wikipedia.
